Headers and footers

Source: vignettes/articles/headers-footers.Rmd
headers-footers.Rmd
library(bs4cards)

As mentioned earlier, the bs4cards package allows you to include headers and footers. However, because of the limitations of bootstrap (or possibly my limitations in using it), it’s not easy to simultaneously align headers, footers, images, and labels in a way that is clean and responsive regardless of the size of the browser window. As a consequence, they’re best suited to cases where you want to discreetly include a small amount of metadata that can be guaranteed to fit on a single line:

galleries %>% 
  cards(
    title = long_name,
    text = blurb,
    link = gallery_url,
    image = image_url,
    width = 4,
    footer = paste("packages:", paintbrushes),
    layout = "label-right"
  )
Ash Cloud and Blood

Simulated watercolours in ggplot2 using the transparent polygon method

packages: ggplot2
Ghosts on Marble Paper

Abstract landscapes generated using ambient

packages: ambient
Ice Floes

Abstract icebergs generated using ambient

packages: ambient
Native Flora

Collections of small flametrees that resemble branching plants

packages: ggplot2 flametree
Silhouettes

Trees generated in flametree with random walk backgrounds

packages: ggplot2 rcpp flametree
Track Marks

Voronoi tessellations with seed points sampled from an iterated function system

packages: ggplot2 rcpp
Viewports

Simple masks with ggfx using flametree-generated textures

packages: ggplot2 flametree

When the text is long enough to potentially occupy multiple lines, more care is needed. The vertical space occupied by a header or footer is calculated independently of each other. This means that when the text in the header/footer varies in length, the cards are no longer guaranteed to be equal in height, producing ragged borders in situations where the user would probably prefer card parts of the same type to be aligned with one another. If you intend to include a header and/or footer, make sure to see how the cards look at different screen sizes and zoom resolutions (more so than usual!)

Developed by Danielle Navarro.
